I am a enthusiastic player of all 4X games, sank lots of hours into the Civ Series, into GalCiv2 and also played Master of Orion 2. And if you expect something of similar quality here, I have to disappoint you:
-The Mechanics: One of the Game Defining Mechanics is how the production works. It works on a global level. Meaning each planet generates global production. If you colonize a second planet the production from the main planet will therefore sink as it's not the only "receiver" anymore. In addition you speed up the production massively with each factory you build. It's almost like reducing the time by half with each factory, which makes no sense. This way you spent a couple of turns building factories, then you design your combat ship, create a couple of them, and kill one "very hard" opponent after the other. Your hardest opponent will be pirates. Balance is completely broken and make all mechanics besides of production and military obsolete. The Global mechanics also kill the feeling of having "special planets". Each planet is just contributing a bit to the "geater good". But that doesn't feel good.
While the game features tactical combat it's not planned out well and as the AI does not focus fire on your ships it will always lose when having troops with even strength.
-The Interface: It works. But it isn't good. Instead of mouseover tooltips you have to click on stuff to get the information, right mousebutton is closing windows. The production windows are tiny, creating a minimum of overview. You also cannot re-arrange your production queue or edit your ship-designs.
-Stability: The game tends to crash after you solved a combat. Within 90 Minutes of the release version the game crashed twice.
-The Music: Is really good, but of course doesn't save the game

Considering that in terms of balancing and game mechanics I didn't see much of a change since I played one of the first alphas I'd say that the chances of getting fixes in the near future is very low. The game has some potential, but in the current state (Release Version / September 2014) I recommend to not buy this game and take a look at the Galactic Civilization 3 Beta instead.

As of 14 Sept 2014 - 

This game is not terrible - just very very bland.

You will not find anything really new in here - all of it exists in other, better made games such as Distant Worlds or GalCiv2.

There are still some major bugs that have not been taken out - I can't even open the trade menu without a crash to desktop.

Ship design is weak - from the start, you get 4 hulls that go from tiny to small - with only no improvements available to increase what you can fit in them. The techs for ships don't provide any options - the missiles, beams and lasers are essentially the same. There are no fighters or bases.

Tactical fights are available but not terribly exciting - nor does it provide any depth as all weapons are in essence identical.

Many of the "management tools" are absent or in very basic form - you can't rearrange build queues, set up rally points, understand how much science, industry, or trade any particular action is going to generate. It's weird how you have to close an empire menu before opening the next one rather than switching between them.

The tech tree is pretty minimal - maybe 50-60 items in total. It gets boring in the 2nd part where you get solid lines of 3-4 consecutive "industry +1" or "research +1". It rarely opens up new abilities, just improves your starting ones.

Minor races have no interaction, except for pirates. You can send a trade ship there, tho with the game maxing out at 4 trade lines, it's not clear why you should bother.

What is working in this game is relatively fine. It just seems like they ran out of time to fine-tune and tweak the content in fun and interesting ways. Perhaps updates wil improve this solid, but it is currently an extremely bland X4 experience.

Verdict - unless you are scrapping the bottom of the barrel for x4 games, skip until a few updates.

column8: Lords of the Crashing Sun is a massive interactive experiment in frustration. I am all for 4x games but having to unplug two of my monitors before the game can run reminds me of my teen days when bootelegged games (they could not be bought back in the days in my town) required us to manipulate autoexec.bat and config.sys so that we could play them. I do not know which part is more depressing, that this was 24 years ago or that this game brought me back to those days. I would honestly like to discuss the gameplay mechanics and merits of turn based vs. real time strategy, but due to an unfortunate second turn crash after I finally got the game running, I have actually spent more time writing this review than playing the game. 15% discount for 100% frustration is sadly not what I was looking for.

I've played this game and I have this to say: It's complete crap. For now. There's still six months' worth of work to be done, ironing out a huge pile of bugs. This starts with endless ship relocations (when saving/loading a game), the inability to create and manage fleets, and ends with the strictly enforced, paltry mass limit for these ships. From the very beginning of the game, you can build ships of any size, including capital ships, and until the end of the game (until you've unlocked all the technologies, which are, frankly, a handful), these ships will have a completely locked mass limit. So, you'll never be able to fill all the slots on your ship. Especially considering that the further you go into the forest, the heavier the modules become, and the less useful they are. Absolutely useless ship modules, serving no purpose whatsoever. The idiotic wreckage recovery system (no matter how well protected and equipped with the latest (though admittedly weak) technology a ship is when inspecting wreckage, there's always a 100% chance it will be destroyed if evil pirates dig in).
The pathetic diplomacy deserves a special mention. When they offer to build their embassy in your country 15 times a year without offering anything in return, it starts to get a bit annoying. And refusals don't change the relationship at all.

All in all it feels like this game is hardly Alpha?

column8:
If I could refund this game, I would. I watched a review of this game from several months ago, and it looked promising. More than promising actually, it looked like it could be an excellent game that combines many of the aspects that I love. Overall, it appears to be something like Sins of a Solar Empire crossed with Civilization crossed with Democracy. The issue was that it was not a finished game.

Jump forward to now, and it is on the front page of Steam, announcing that it is a finished game. FAR FROM IT. I should have looked more at the fine text, but the developer says that even though it is moving out of early access, it stills needs patching. This is evident from the start. The intro splash took quite some time to load, even on a fairly powerful computer and locked my screen to the program until it finished. Typos and grammatical errors are common, even on the first few small text boxes of the tutorial. Additionally, the textures are rediculously poor on higher zoom levels, even on max graphical settings. What sealed the deal for me though was the frequent crashing brought about by this game. 

Again, though this game has promise, it is not yet ready. I feel as though I was tricked into buy an incomplete game. The saddest part of it is that if this game came out in a ready state, I might have loved it. But my initial play has only served to frusturate me.

The game feels very simple and basic. There is nothing to this game that I wouldnt expect from any other x4 game, and this is still on the light side of 4x games. It does not get very in depth with any game mechanic. Combat is mediocre, Diplomacy is mediocre, research is very limited with a relatively small research tree compared to other more recent 4x games. All in all, the game is just bland and sub par. Honestly, it feels like playing a unity based game in a web browser. I would expect to find similar mechanics and gameplay from a free game site.

Its also not stable. When creating a game, picking certain map settings could cause a crash. First battle I lost, caused a crash. Within a period of 30 minutes just to check out the full release version, I had 3 crashes.

I really love the sci-fi space based 4x genre, and I wanted this game to be good because there are so few games in this genre that can hold a candle to what MoO2 was for its time. This game does not get close. I would not recommend this game to anyone, not even casual players.

column8:
This game sounds good, but even in the Early Acess and room to grow - I don't see it compare with the scope it wants to attain.

-/- the major races are restrictive, and doesn't include any customization option at the start up.
-/+ instead there is a slight reimagining of "Domestic Polocies" that can further define and charactarize your empire, you can change them during the game and alter some aspects slightly - but there are pros and cons to them and often a particular race will just prefer a certain setup.

-/- the universe is limited, with little options outside colonizing a few planets you can take, and attack or occupy others. There isn't much interaction with the universe as a whole outside it being a static generation from the start. Perhaps I was spoiled with Space Empire's abiolities to drastically reform the universe even while in the game, but here its marginal.
-/- even with another strike against it is the "neutral" races or "pirates" which are just a bit more than just target practice and nuciances occupying a planet you want.

-/- the diplomacy feels shallow. I am sorry, its just not as in depth as I have seen others - it can be altered to get there sure, but as it stands I don't see it shifting to that. Many of the diplomacy options require facility constructions that will limit your options on the planets you own, and some options won't happen unless you or the other race have room to invest, further limiting who is really benefitting.

-/- the tactical turn based combat is restrictive as hell. You only get to do so much per turn, and each ship is further limited by its loadout. Multiple loadout designs with different weapon types or perks limits the ship's ability to function as you can only do one per turn, making the combat really limited in scope to the design and swarming of a few cheap ship creations of a doubled weapon or three.

-/- this further falls under the ship construction as there are limited sizes and options for what can be loaded on which ship. It limits design and role choices heavily.

+/- the genreals are a cool idea that develop as you use them, but the risk and reward are staggering comparisions. Due to the combat being so restrictive there isn't much for strategic desings possible and the random generation of the generals is flawed at times - they may have an attack power, but without a type given so it doesn't work. The development of them can be cool, and it directly affects their strengths, however the combat risk can easily leave them out on a limb and you'll loose all your progress.

-/+ the unrest aspect is interesting, but difficult to cause and easy to avoid, making it a moot issue that rarely surfaces unless you let or make it.

-/+ further deplomacy aspects sound cool as well, but the AI is fineky on its choices making its fulfuilment in many regards challenging, or just a question of finaces. A good economy can basically buy allies in most cases wtih a bit of espionage fixing.

-/- the AI cheats. I'm sorry, it does. It doesn't do something its not confident it can win, making it more hesitant and dulling the gameplay. Set up safe enough even with cheap ships and you'll never be threatened as you grow until you amass that army to just wipe everything out.


Sounds good, can be interesting - but I've seen other 4x games pull off similarities better, so its not really worth it for most.

column8:
I dont recomend playing this game unless micro-management of a few dozen things at once sounds like a great time to you. 

The first time I played I loaded up on as many AI opponents as I could and a huge galaxy. I made one attack on a pirate faction and then every race hated me and started going to war with me. I was also experiencing some learning curve set-backs, so I quit out of that game and started a new one. 

Round 2 I went with just 2 alien AI opponents, in a small galaxy, and tried just making nice with them. We claimed our planets, established trade routes, built stuff.... 5 hours later nothing had happened. I was basically just making the same colony ships over and over, going to new planets, building the same buildings... My population was happy, my enemies were all happy, I had more money than I knew what to do with. The game kind of just devolved into a management of the empires finances and construction. 

This game is really lacking from random events that spice up your experience. They attempted by puting in 'disasters' which is basically just a simple: 'pay money and keep people happy' or 'Tell your people you wont help them and piss everyone off'. Its a pretty shallow wildcard system. 

The interface is clean, but is also very lacking. For example, when looking at what buildings are on a planet, only the 'build menu' has the names of the buildings and what they do. The buildings you already have in place do not have names, and you cannot click on them to see if they are being effective in any way. So you have to do a cross reference on what the buildings look like to even know what you have built... 

And on the subject of building, its super boring. I'm sure I would eventually get to more advanced structures down the tech tree, but in the 5-8 hours I played Puting the same combination of 5-10 buildings on 20 different planets was about as much fun as organizing a deck of cards. Also it seems when you do unlock better versions of buildings, you need to go BACK to all of those planets, destroy a building, and put in the upgrade. Its not automatic. 

So when you are 20 hours down the line in this game and you wonder why every race has a better economy than you, it might be because you forgot to upgrade 5 of your 40 planets to better factories... better go check them all... one... by... one.... 

While I cant recomend this game I hope that the developers learn from this one and make a sequel with the holes filled in. It's a great idea, It just relies WAY too much on the player to micro manage all of their systems.

This game has a real bright future, for a number of reasons too.
When you begin playing the gmae, you are presented with a beatiful represenation of the galaxy you have chosen (You can customize this galaxy in certain ways as well) and as you venture further into creating the strongest galactic empire possible, you begin to see the possibilities that could be implemented, knowing that this is currently early access. The game really draws you in and you start to wonder which way you want your empire to go, and the game gives you many ways to go. It does this through their social policy system, where you are presented with different social policies and how your citizens feel about them.  These attitudes will change over time and you will have to decide whether to legalize slavery or keep it banned (for example). The game also has a unique addition that really allows you to decide the , lets say attitude, of your empire and it is ship design. At the start, you have 3 pre-set ships, scout, colony ship and army ship. The army ship is only transport, so the game urges you to create your own battleship and in the process, you start planning your own ships. For example, after researching intergalactic trade, you will need to create a tradeship, so you would need to add a trading module and an engine, but you then need to decide whether armour or weapons would serve more of a purpose, as the trade modul weighs  a good 30 tonnes. This is just one example of the many aspects that makes Lords of the Black Sun a brilliant game with a bright future. I would strongly recommend this game.

I got this game Late last year.  I love 4x games of all types but scifi space 4x is my fav. 同ジャンルの神ゲー Imperium Galactica 2 のような雰囲気があり期待していたのだが、、
これからのアップデートに期待したい（致命的なバグだらけでプレイするのもイヤになるｗ）
アップデ来なかったら唯のマゾゲーですよ？(クソゲではない)
$19.99で買ったけど、$3でも高いと思いますよ
三回もやり直してるけど、現状じゃこれ以上はもうむりぽ

追記：
なんだかんだで５回やり直してなんとかクリアした感想という愚痴をココに書きます。

セーブデータが頻繁に壊れる、整合性がとれずにCTD
初期化できずにCTD、戦闘突入時に敵の艦隊がＰＣ側として読み込まれてCTD
敵の将軍が読み込まれてバグってフリーズする、特定の日付で敵が攻め込んでくるとCTD、特定の日付で敵を攻める・宙域で戦闘を行うとCTD
特定の座標で戦闘するとCTD、惑星を占領するとCTD、艦隊が何故か増えて次のターンでCTD、生産された艦隊が消滅してCTD
ＮＰＣ、ＰＣの支配惑星・艦隊らが共に消滅しCTD、
セーブした瞬間（オートセーブ含む）にCTD
ゲーム中にロードするとCTD (但し、一度ゲームを中断してタイトルからロードすれば落ちないが、今度はセーブデータがロード出来なくなる事がある）
数ターン前のセーブデータ・オートセーブがロード出来ずに積む
などと苦痛しか味わえない稀代のマゾゲ。




ゲームとしてはマップの拡大縮小が大雑把で使いづらい、
艦隊の行き先がＡ点→Ｂ点までしか指示できずに複数の艦隊を運用する上で使い難い
すべての技術を完成させても入植できない惑星がある。
小型艦・中型艦・大型艦・主力艦という区切りはあるが、空母の概念、攻撃する方向によりダメージや命中率が変化するなどの概念がない為、戦闘が単調でつまらない。
特殊装備の使いどころがない。（全艦艇ミサイル装備して突っ込ませておけば大体勝てる）
自動戦闘のバランスがおかしい（hp:20,arm:9 主力艦 x 8 vs hp:11,arm:0 中型艦 x 2 で主力艦側が全滅など)
傭兵として使役する将軍の存在が微妙（艦をアップグレード出来ないので最初は盾に使えても中盤では弾除けにすらならない）

ようやくクリアしたが、エンディング的なものはおろか
クレジットすら出ないとは、、あっさりしてます。

現在のバージョンでは金と時間の無駄使いです、まだCapcomのつまらんゾンビゲの方がマシ。
column9:
Debugging errors, errors, errors.
The game crashes when loading, freezes during battle, freezes after defeating enemies,
endless loading times, and sometimes even crashes. It's so buggy, I can't help but wonder if they even debugged it.

It has a similar feel to the legendary game Imperium Galactica 2, but...
I was really looking forward to it. (It's full of fatal bugs that make me hate playing it lol.)
If there's no update, it'll just be a masochistic game, right? (It's not a crappy game.)
I bought it for $19.99, but even $3 seems like a bit much.
I've tried it three times, and at this point, I'm not ready to play any more.

PS:
After five tries, I finally managed to complete it, so here's my rant and my thoughts.

Save data frequently corrupts, crashes due to inconsistency
Crashes when unable to initialize, crashes when enemy fleet is loaded as PC's when entering battle
Bugs and freezes when enemy general is loaded, crashes when enemy attacks on a specific date, crashes when attacking enemy or fighting in space on a specific date
Crashes when fighting at specific coordinates, crashes when occupying a planet, fleets somehow increase and crashes the next turn, CTD when produced fleets disappear
Crashes when NPCs, PC's controlled planets, and fleets all disappear,
Crashes the moment you save (including autosaves)
Crashes when loading during the game (however, if you pause the game and load from the title screen, it doesn't crash, but then save data sometimes won't load)
Save data from a few turns ago and autosaves won't load, leaving the game stuck
This is a rare masochistic game that's nothing but painful.

As a game, the map's zoom is rough and difficult to use.
Fleets can only be directed from point A to point B, making it difficult to operate multiple fleets.
There are planets that cannot be colonized even after all technologies have been perfected.
While there are divisions into small, medium, large, and capital ships, there's no concept of aircraft carriers or how damage or hit rate changes depending on the direction of attack, making battles monotonous and boring.
Special equipment is not used. (If you equip all ships with missiles and let them charge, you'll usually win.)
Auto-combat is unbalanced (e.g., 8 capital ships with 20 HP and 9 Armor vs. 2 medium ships with 11 HP and 0 Armor resulting in the capital ships being completely wiped out).
The generals employed as mercenaries are questionable (ships can't be upgraded, so while they may be useful as shields at first, they don't even offer much protection in the middle of the game).

I finally completed the game, but there's no ending, not even a credit...that's so simple.

The current version is a waste of money and time, I'd rather play Capcom's boring zombie game.

column8:
Star Lords Alpha Build - Pre-release Review

Star Lords, by Arkavi Studios and Iceberg Interactive is a deep and complex turn based 4x sci-fy strategy game. This is about the only informations you get from the get-go once you boot the game for the first time. Once you start a new game, you will be asked to select from a group of 8 original races and customise the "game board".

Once the game begins, you'll immediately take control of your chosen race and you can start using your scout ship to explore your surroundings. You also get a home planet, which will be  used as a main hub for initial development.

The game leaves a pretty good first impression, with very nice and clean graphical information. The UI is functional and simple, but can become a bit overwhelming for starters, but all in all everything is pretty intuitive. But, being this an alpha build, i must stress the importance of the creation of a structured tutorial, so players can learn and try the base mechanics before being sent into the wild.

Once the game starts building up pace, you will meet other civilizations, which you will need to either crush with military prowess or outsmart through diplomacy and espionage. Overall, the AI is pretty solid, even though other races can be tad temperamental towards your actions 

The game map, even though presented in a very simplistic fashion, works very well and offers a ton of graphical variety. Planets look pretty good, and so does spacial debris and other celestial bodies, such as moons and stars.

The game still lacks a bit of clear indicative elements, such as an "it is now your turn" prompt, or some audio feedback on research completion but, as it is in alpha, hopefully these elements will be added at some point.

Veredict: There is room for a lot of improvement, specially in the fine details, but as this is just an alpha build, i will be eagerly expecting the finished product, and i am glad to be supporting it!
